rows.title: Breathe to three

transcript.eng:
Close your eyes. 

Use the magic power of three to stay connected and relax.

Breathe in to the count of three. 1, 2, 3. 
Breathe out to the count of three. 1, 2, 3. 
Breathe in to the count of three. 1, 2, 3. 
Breathe out to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.

Do you feel any different? Deep breathing helps our whole body and mind to calm down. 

You are a star!

Breathe out to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.

Do you feel any different? Deep breathing helps our whole body and mind to calm down. 

You are a star!

text_1.eng: Recognising how you feel is key to handling life well. Be real and kind to yourself.

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: You are a star. And you are making a real difference. You can be proud of yourself.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Everyone has good and bad days. Well done for using this app. It shows you are a committed parent. Remember to praise yourself for it!

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Sorry that things are not easy today. All parents have these days. You are trying and moving forward!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today's topic is about giving positive instructions!

Telling our teens what we DO want them to do works better than telling them to STOP doing something.

You will see the difference.

media_title.eng: Giving positive instructions really works! Tap play to learn more

media_transcript.eng:
Greetings, greetings everyone.

Today our topic is positive instructions.

It is important to give positive instructions to our children, because when we give them positive instructions they know and understand what we are expecting them to do and they do it the way we want them to do it.

So, at the end it keeps everyone happy.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today's topic is about giving positive instructions!

Telling our teens what we DO want them to do works better than telling them to STOP doing something.

You will see the difference.
rows.media_title: Giving positive instructions really works! Tap play to learn more
rows.media_transcript:
Greetings, greetings everyone.

Today our topic is positive instructions.

It is important to give positive instructions to our children, because when we give them positive instructions they know and understand what we are expecting them to do and they do it the way we want them to do it.

So, at the end it keeps everyone happy.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
When you give positive instructions, your teen is more likely to listen! 

And remember to praise your teen for any good behaviour - the big and small things.

media_title.eng: Press play to hear how positive instructions worked for @data.characters.media_female_3.name and her teens

media_transcript.eng:
Before, I used to raise my teens the way I was raised: I would tell them “don’t do this, don’t do that.” We used to fight a lot, but things have really changed when I learnt about giving positive instructions.

Now I focus on the behaviour I want to see, and give clear and simple instructions to my teens. It took time to learn to say “please do this” instead of “don’t do this.”

My teens and even my husband tell me that they love this way of doing things, because now they know what needs to be done. My teen said one day “I really love this new mom,” and my own stress levels have come down a lot.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
When you give positive instructions, your teen is more likely to listen! 

And remember to praise your teen for any good behaviour - the big and small things.
rows.media_title: Press play to hear how positive instructions worked for @data.characters.media_female_3.name and her teens
rows.media_transcript:
Before, I used to raise my teens the way I was raised: I would tell them “don’t do this, don’t do that.” We used to fight a lot, but things have really changed when I learnt about giving positive instructions.

Now I focus on the behaviour I want to see, and give clear and simple instructions to my teens. It took time to learn to say “please do this” instead of “don’t do this.”

My teens and even my husband tell me that they love this way of doing things, because now they know what needs to be done. My teen said one day “I really love this new mom,” and my own stress levels have come down a lot.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Let’s do a thought experiment!

DO NOT THINK ABOUT AN ELEPHANT.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Let’s do a thought experiment!

DO NOT THINK ABOUT AN ELEPHANT.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
What are you thinking about? 

You probably DID think about an elephant...

text_2.eng:
In the same way, when we tell our teens “don’t do that,” they often focus only on the thing we told them not to do.
They may not understand what we *DO* want.

And like most of us, they don’t enjoy being told what not to do.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
What are you thinking about? 

You probably DID think about an elephant...
rows.text_2:
In the same way, when we tell our teens “don’t do that,” they often focus only on the thing we told them not to do.
They may not understand what we *DO* want.

And like most of us, they don’t enjoy being told what not to do.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
NOW, THINK ABOUT A CHEETAH!

What are you thinking about?

rows.text_1_facilitator:
NOW, THINK ABOUT A CHEETAH!

What are you thinking about?

text_1_facilitator.eng:
That’s right! Positive, clear instructions help teens focus on what they should be doing.

Teens will also feel more respected this way and are more likely to listen.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
That’s right! Positive, clear instructions help teens focus on what they should be doing.

Teens will also feel more respected this way and are more likely to listen.

character_1_text.eng: Don’t make such a mess while I am cleaning the house. You are in the way!

text_1_facilitator.eng: Here are some tips to help you give your teen clear and positive instructions!

section_1_text.eng: Can your teen actually do what you are about to ask? It may be impossible for them to read quietly all day, but half an hour when you really need it is realistic.

section_2_text.eng: Smile, look them in the eye and use positive words. Praise them as soon as they start to do what you ask!

section_3_text.eng: Often we know what we want in our head, but we don’t say it clearly enough. Say exactly what you want your teen to do. Try ‘please come home by 7pm’ instead of ‘come home on time’.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Here are some tips to help you give your teen clear and positive instructions!
rows.section_1_text: Can your teen actually do what you are about to ask? It may be impossible for them to read quietly all day, but half an hour when you really need it is realistic.
rows.section_2_text: Smile, look them in the eye and use positive words. Praise them as soon as they start to do what you ask!
rows.section_3_text: Often we know what we want in our head, but we don’t say it clearly enough. Say exactly what you want your teen to do. Try ‘please come home by 7pm’ instead of ‘come home on time’.

text_1_facilitator.eng: This week's home activity is to give your teen positive instructions.

text_2.eng: Remember, teenagers are much more likely to listen when we give positive, clear and realistic instructions.

quiz_1_question.eng: Can you give your teen positive instructions this week?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: That's great! Well done for trying. You will see the difference it makes.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: You can do it! Notice when you normally say ‘don’t do this!’ and think of a positive way to phrase it. You can try it out and see what happens.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: That's okay. It can be hard to try something new. Could you think of one situation where you often tell your teen ‘don’t do this’? Try to find a positive way to give that instruction.

quiz_2_question.eng:
Let’s do a quick practice to help you prepare for your home activity! 
Turn each of these instructions into positive ones:

quiz_2_option_1_text.eng: 👕 Stop leaving your dirty clothes all over the place!

quiz_2_feedback_1.eng: You could say: "I know you’ve had a long day. Could you please put your clothes in the basket so it’s easier to keep things tidy? Thanks – it really helps."

quiz_2_option_2_text.eng: 🎵 Stop playing your music so loud in the house!

quiz_2_feedback_2.eng: You could say: "That’s great music. Who is the singer? Please turn the music off when you come into the house. You can play it in your room quietly if you want. Thank you!"

quiz_2_option_3_text.eng: 📱 Stop playing on your phone at the dinner table!

quiz_2_feedback_3.eng: You could say: "I like that you enjoy your phone. Can you put it away during dinner so we can spend time together? Thanks – I really appreciate it."

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: That's great! Well done for trying. You will see the difference it makes.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: You can do it! Notice when you normally say ‘don’t do this!’ and think of a positive way to phrase it. You can try it out and see what happens.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: That's okay. It can be hard to try something new. Could you think of one situation where you often tell your teen ‘don’t do this’? Try to find a positive way to give that instruction.

text_1_facilitator.eng: More positive instructions means less frustrations. And that is something we all want, right?

media_title.eng: Hear how positive instructions helped @data.characters.media_daughter_3.name and her mother

media_transcript.eng:
At first, I did not care much that my mother was doing with @global.app_name. But then I started to see my mother change how she communicated with us.

One day, when I was going out with my friends, she said I must be home by 6pm. I was like “Hmmm okay,” because she normally did not give clear instructions on what she wanted – she would just say nothing and then shout at me for being late when I got home.

When I got home around 5pm, my mother gave me a hug and said “Thank you for being on time.” It was strange, but I liked it.

Since then, we have much clearer communication in the house.

rows.text_1_facilitator: More positive instructions means less frustrations. And that is something we all want, right?
rows.media_title: Hear how positive instructions helped @data.characters.media_daughter_3.name and her mother
rows.media_transcript:
At first, I did not care much that my mother was doing with @global.app_name. But then I started to see my mother change how she communicated with us.

One day, when I was going out with my friends, she said I must be home by 6pm. I was like “Hmmm okay,” because she normally did not give clear instructions on what she wanted – she would just say nothing and then shout at me for being late when I got home.

When I got home around 5pm, my mother gave me a hug and said “Thank you for being on time.” It was strange, but I liked it.

Since then, we have much clearer communication in the house.
